**G.L. c. 186, \u00a714**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, §14**, a landlord “shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises.”

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a78**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under **G.L. c. 223, §8**, because the premises at issue are located in Springfield, Massachusetts.

**G.L. c. 218, \u00a719**.proposition: The amount in controversy does not exceed $7,000, placing this case within the jurisdiction of the Springfield District Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, §19**.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A (tenant remedies f.raw_text: G.L. c. 239, §8A (tenant remedies for code violations)
G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A (tenant remedies f.proposition: - G.L. c. 239, §8A (tenant remedies for code violations)

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: The covenant protects tenants against both affirmative acts and omissions that materially deprive lawful possession and beneficial use.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The court expressly rejects any distinction between landlord malfeasance and nonfeasance and holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when a substantial deprivation of use is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done. The opinion emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling, and relies on prior cases involving both affirmative acts and failures to act, thereby supporting that the covenant protects tenants against both types of conduct when they materially deprive lawful possession and beneficial use.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling… we decline to perpetuate that distinction between nonfeasance… and malfeasance…”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant protects tenants against both affirmative acts and omissions that materially deprive lawful possession and beneficial use.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment both at common law and under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and makes clear that it reaches serious interferences caused by a landlord’s conduct or omissions that impair the character and value of the premises. The court emphasizes that liability does not require malicious intent and that the landlord’s failure to act to prevent unsanitary flooding, despite complaints and a duty to maintain sanitary conditions, constituted an interference with quiet enjoyment. This aligns with the proposition that the covenant protects tenants against affirmative acts and omissions that materially deprive lawful possession and beneficial use.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Constructive interference includes the landlord’s failure to maintain essential utilities, as recognized in *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997), and *Meikle v. Nurse*, 474 Mass. 207 (2016).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion in Al-Ziab concerns whether a statutory lead paint violation, by itself, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It clarifies that liability under § 14 requires at least negligent conduct and notice, but it does not discuss utilities or define constructive interference in terms of a landlord’s failure to maintain essential utilities. Thus, the case does not support the specific proposition that constructive interference includes failure to maintain essential utilities.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

*Meikle v. Nurse*, 474 Mass. 207 (2016).proposition: Constructive interference includes the landlord’s failure to maintain essential utilities, as recognized in *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997), and *Meikle v. Nurse*, 474 Mass. 207 (2016).
*Meikle v. Nurse*, 474 Mass. 207 (2016).support_reasoning: The opinion in Meikle v. Nurse is about whether violations of the security deposit statute qualify as a counterclaim/defense under G.L. c. 239, § 8A in a summary process action. It does not address, define, or apply the concept of constructive interference or constructive eviction, nor does it discuss failures to maintain essential utilities. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition that constructive interference includes failure to maintain essential utilities.
*Meikle v. Nurse*, 474 Mass. 207 (2016).relevant_excerpt: “In the context of a summary process action, we have no difficulty interpreting the phrase ‘violation of any other law’ to include any law enacted to protect a tenant’s rights in the landlord-tenant relationship. … The security deposit statute is one such law. Indeed, the security deposit statute has no raison d’être other than to insure fairness to a tenant who pays a sum to the landlord and relies on the landlord’s good faith for the return of the portion to which he or she is entitled at the end of the tenancy.”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Electric service is an essential service whose interruption renders premises partially uninhabitable under *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979) and *Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, 437 Mass. 708 (2002).
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion in Berman squarely concerns loss of heat and hot water as material breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and the timing of rent abatement. It does not discuss electric service at all, nor does it characterize electricity as an essential service or state that interruption of electric service renders premises (partially) uninhabitable. Thus, while Berman supports the broader idea that failures of essential building services can make premises uninhabitable, it is not authority for this specific proposition about electric service.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition… We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability.”

*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, 437.proposition: Electric service is an essential service whose interruption renders premises partially uninhabitable under *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979) and *Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, 437 Mass. 708 (2002).
*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, 437.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss interruption of essential services as a basis for constructive eviction and cites earlier Massachusetts cases (including Brown v. Holyoke Water Power Co. and Charles E. Burt, Inc.) where loss of power was treated as such. However, Wesson itself does not characterize electric service as an essential service rendering premises partially uninhabitable, nor does it involve an electric-service interruption; its holding concerns a leaking roof and the adoption of mutually dependent covenants in commercial leases. Thus, it does not directly establish the specific proposition claimed about electric service and partial uninhabitability under Berman and Wesson.
*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, 437.relevant_excerpt: “Thus, a landlord’s failure to provide a service that is essential to the use and enjoyment of the demised premises may qualify as a constructive eviction.15 … See Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 126-128 (1959) (landlord’s failure to provide essential services, including electric power, heat, and elevator services, for six-month period found to be constructive eviction of commercial tenant)… Brown v. Holyoke Water Power Co., 152 Mass. 463, 464 (1890) (landlord constructively evicted tenant manufacturer by permanently disconnecting all power to machinery).”}`}

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s inaction in repairing the wiring constitutes a “serious interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment” as defined by *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Lowery v. Robinson holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season constitutes a serious interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The opinion does not address electrical wiring, repairs to wiring, or inaction regarding wiring specifically. Using Lowery as authority that failure to repair wiring is a serious interference with quiet enjoyment overstates and misdescribes the actual holding, which is limited to lack of heat as a code-required service.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.proposition: A landlord’s failure to respond diligently to electrical defects after notice is “interference” within the meaning of §14.
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.support_reasoning: The case interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s covenant of quiet enjoyment in the context of drug activity and a landlord’s failure to take measures to remove nontenants, not in the context of electrical defects. The court states that a landlord may be liable for § 14 interference if it “failed to take any measures” to remove unwelcome persons whose presence seriously interferes with the tenancy, but it does not discuss electrical defects or treat failure to diligently repair physical conditions as “interference” under § 14. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition about electrical defects.
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.relevant_excerpt: “We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.proposition: The Defendant’s conduct also constitutes a breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment recognized at common law.
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.support_reasoning: This portion of Hemingway (a concurrence/dissent) discusses implied warranty of habitability and implied contractual obligations based on housing codes, not the common‑law implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. It neither analyzes quiet enjoyment nor describes code violations as a breach of that covenant; the majority’s quiet-enjoyment discussion is elsewhere in the case. Accordingly, this text does not support the proposition that the defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment recognized at common law.
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.relevant_excerpt: "As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tentant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards."
